clusters.title: Party balloon or cartel drones? Closure of El Paso airspace causes 'chaos'
clusters.neutral_headline: El Paso Airspace Closure Causes Chaos

items.title: Party balloon or cartel drones? Closure of El Paso airspace causes 'chaos'
items.standfirst: The sudden and unexpected closure of the airspace over El Paso, Texas, appears to have stemmed from the US federal government conducting drone-related tests. The 10-day closure, which ultimately ended hours after it was announced late Tuesday, caused a mass panic in the US-Mexico border city, with…
items.content: The sudden and unexpected closure of the airspace over El Paso, Texas, appears to have stemmed from the US federal government conducting drone-related tests. The 10-day closure, which ultimately ended hours after it was announced late Tuesday, caused a mass panic in the US-Mexico border city, with…

items.title: Party balloon or cartel drones? Closure of El Paso airspace causes 'chaos'
items.standfirst: The sudden 10-day closure of El Paso's airspace reportedly followed a spat over drone technology testing by the US military.
items.content: The sudden 10-day closure of El Paso's airspace reportedly followed a spat over drone technology testing by the US military.

items.title: US officials lift 10-day closure of El Paso airspace after balloon mistaken for drone
items.standfirst: FAA initially cited ‘security reasons’ for shutting off skies around Texas airport in area along border with MexicoThe top US aviation agency has lifted a surprise 10-day closure of airspace above the US-Mexico border town of El Paso, Texas, just hours after it abruptly announced that it would close off the skies for “special security reasons”.While some officials claimed that Mexican cartel drones invaded US airspace, in recent days a balloon was reportedly mistaken for a drone. Continue reading...
items.content: FAA initially cited ‘security reasons’ for shutting off skies around Texas airport in area along border with MexicoThe top US aviation agency has lifted a surprise 10-day closure of airspace above the US-Mexico border town of El Paso, Texas, just hours after it abruptly announced that it would close off the skies for “special security reasons”.While some officials claimed that Mexican cartel drones invaded US airspace, in recent days a balloon was reportedly mistaken for a drone. Continue reading...

items.title: Airspace closure followed FAA, Pentagon spat over drone-related tests, sources say
items.standfirst: Pentagon officials had undertaken planning to use military technology near Fort Bliss, in El Paso, to practice downing drones.
items.content: Pentagon officials had undertaken planning to use military technology near Fort Bliss, in El Paso, to practice downing drones.

items.title: El Paso airspace closure due to use of U.S. military anti-drone technology
items.standfirst: The Federal Aviation Administration abruptly closed the airspace around El Paso, only to reopen it hours later. The bizarre episode pointed to a lack of coordination between the FAA and the Pentagon.
items.content: The Federal Aviation Administration abruptly closed the airspace around El Paso, only to reopen it hours later. The bizarre episode pointed to a lack of coordination between the FAA and the Pentagon.(Image credit: Morgan Lee)

ai_summary: El Paso airspace closed due to US government drone tests
Closure caused mass panic in the US-Mexico border city
FAA cited security reasons for the shutdown
A balloon was mistaken for a drone, prompting the closure
The airspace was reopened hours after the announcement

clusters.title: ‘Nothing definitive’ reached about Iran during Netanyahu’s visit with Trump

items.title: ‘Nothing definitive’ reached about Iran during Netanyahu’s visit with Trump
items.standfirst: US president says he 'insisted' that negotiations with Iran will continue and that 'progress' was being made on Gaza.
items.content: US president says he 'insisted' that negotiations with Iran will continue and that 'progress' was being made on Gaza.

items.title: Trump tells Netanyahu Iran nuclear talks must continue
items.standfirst: The US President said "nothing definitive" was agreed during the meeting between the two leaders at the White House on Wednesday as nuclear talks intensify.
items.content: The US President said "nothing definitive" was agreed during the meeting between the two leaders at the White House on Wednesday as nuclear talks intensify.

items.title: Trump ‘insisted’ that US talks with Iran will continue as Netanyahu pushes for their expansion
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Wednesday said he had “insisted” in a meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that Washington’s resumed talks with Iran over its nuclear programme will continue, but that no “definitive” agreement had been reached. Netanyahu wants to expand the negotiations to include Tehran’s ballistic missile programme.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Wednesday said he had “insisted” in a meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that Washington’s resumed talks with Iran over its nuclear programme will continue, but that no “definitive” agreement had been reached. Netanyahu wants to expand the negotiations to include Tehran’s ballistic missile programme.

items.title: 'Netanyahu concerned that Trump wants to make a deal with Iran', expert says
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stressed to US President Donald Trump that his country's security was his priority in Washington's nuclear talks with Iran, Netanyahu's office said in a statement after the two leaders met at the White House. FRANCE 24's Mark Owen speaks with Dr H.A. Hellyer, Senior Fellow in Geopolitics at the Royal United Services Institute in London.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stressed to US President Donald Trump that his country's security was his priority in Washington's nuclear talks with Iran, Netanyahu's office said in a statement after the two leaders met at the White House. FRANCE 24's Mark Owen speaks with Dr H.A. Hellyer, Senior Fellow in Geopolitics at the Royal United Services Institute in London.

items.title: Iran rules out broader U.S. talks as Trump hints at sending 2nd carrier
items.standfirst: Iran insisted Wednesday that it was willing to negotiate with the United States over its nuclear program, but it ruled out broader talks at a pivotal moment in diplomacy between Washington and Tehran
items.content: Iran insisted Wednesday that it was willing to negotiate with the United States over its nuclear program, but it ruled out broader talks at a pivotal moment in diplomacy between Washington and Tehran

items.title: Iran tells US not to let Netanyahu thwart nuclear talks before Trump meeting
items.standfirst: Tehran’s intervention comes as the Israeli prime minister heads to a hastily arranged White House encounterTehran has told the US not to allow Israel to destroy the chance of reaching an agreement over Iran’s nuclear programme amid speculation that Benjamin Netanyahu intends to use a hastily arranged White House meeting with Donald Trump on Wednesday to divert negotiations.Iran’s intervention came as the Israeli prime minister flew to Washington to plead with Trump not to negotiate a deal with Tehran if it excludes limiting the country’s ballistic missile programme, dropping its support for proxy forces in the region and curtailing human rights abuses at home. Continue reading...
items.content: Tehran’s intervention comes as the Israeli prime minister heads to a hastily arranged White House encounterTehran has told the US not to allow Israel to destroy the chance of reaching an agreement over Iran’s nuclear programme amid speculation that Benjamin Netanyahu intends to use a hastily arranged White House meeting with Donald Trump on Wednesday to divert negotiations.Iran’s intervention came as the Israeli prime minister flew to Washington to plead with Trump not to negotiate a deal with Tehran if it excludes limiting the country’s ballistic missile programme, dropping its support for proxy forces in the region and curtailing human rights abuses at home. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Trump and Netanyahu met at the White House to discuss Iran
Trump insisted that US talks with Iran will continue
No definitive agreement was reached during the meeting
Netanyahu wants to expand negotiations to include Tehran's missile program
Iran ruled out broader talks with the US

clusters.title: Milan-Cortina 2026: Golden day for France's Simon and ice dancing duo Cizeron, Fournier Beaudry
clusters.neutral_headline: France Wins Ice Dance Gold At 2026 Olympics

items.title: Milan-Cortina 2026: Golden day for France's Simon and ice dancing duo Cizeron, Fournier Beaudry
items.standfirst: It was a banner day for Team France on February 11, 2026, at the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics. In the women's 15km individual biathlon, Julia Simon claimed gold ahead of teammate Lou Jeanmonnot, who took silver. In moguls, Perrine Laffont grabbed bronze, eight years after her PyeongChang triumph. The highlight came on the ice, where Laurence Fournier Beaudry and Guillaume Cizeron won Olympic gold in figure skating.
items.content: It was a banner day for Team France on February 11, 2026, at the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics. In the women's 15km individual biathlon, Julia Simon claimed gold ahead of teammate Lou Jeanmonnot, who took silver. In moguls, Perrine Laffont grabbed bronze, eight years after her PyeongChang triumph. The highlight came on the ice, where Laurence Fournier Beaudry and Guillaume Cizeron won Olympic gold in figure skating.

items.title: Madison Chock and Evan Bates claim silver in ice dance at 2026 Winter Olympics
items.standfirst: Madison Chock and Evan Bates claimed a silver medal at the 2026 Winter Olympics on Wednesday following a stunning free dance routine.
items.content: Madison Chock and Evan Bates claimed a silver medal at the 2026 Winter Olympics on Wednesday following a stunning free dance routine.

items.title: USA's Madison Chock and Evan Bates win ice dance silver after France's stunning upset
items.standfirst: Chock and Bates, four-time Olympians, were heavily favored for gold. But they lost by less than two points to a French duo who has been clouded by controversy involving their former partners.
items.content: Chock and Bates, four-time Olympians, were heavily favored for gold. But they lost by less than two points to a French duo who has been clouded by controversy involving their former partners.(Image credit: Francisco Seco)

items.title: France’s Cizeron, Fournier Beaudry win ice dance gold at 2026 Olympics
items.standfirst: French figure skaters Guillaume Cizeron and Laurence Fournier Beaudry won Olympic gold in ice dance on Wednesday, capping a remarkable rise after pairing up just one year ago. The duo topped reigning world champions Madison Chock and Evan Bates of the United States following the free dance final.
items.content: French figure skaters Guillaume Cizeron and Laurence Fournier Beaudry won Olympic gold in ice dance on Wednesday, capping a remarkable rise after pairing up just one year ago. The duo topped reigning world champions Madison Chock and Evan Bates of the United States following the free dance final.

ai_summary: French duo Cizeron and Fournier Beaudry won ice dance gold
They topped US champions Madison Chock and Evan Bates
The French pair won by less than two points
Julia Simon won gold in the women's 15km individual biathlon
Perrine Laffont grabbed bronze in the moguls event

items.title: It wasn’t a dry January for the job market
items.standfirst: Despite low expectations spurred by words of warning from a White House official, the US added a surprisingly high 130,000 jobs last month and saw the unemployment rate come in at a better-than-expected 4.3%, according to the highly anticipated jobs report released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor…
items.content: Despite low expectations spurred by words of warning from a White House official, the US added a surprisingly high 130,000 jobs last month and saw the unemployment rate come in at a better-than-expected 4.3%, according to the highly anticipated jobs report released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor…

items.title: US added 130,000 jobs in January, surpassing expectations as 2025 growth is slashed
items.standfirst: Unemployment rate was 4.3% in January with gains 13,000 less than the 143,000 jobs added a year ago, report showsThe US jobs market added 130,000 jobs in January, according to a highly anticipated labor market report released on Wednesday, a surge of job growth after months of fatigue in the labor market.The unemployment rate was 4.3% in January, a slight cooling since the fall. Economists predicted 70,000 in job gains and an unchanged unemployment rate for January. Continue reading...
items.content: Unemployment rate was 4.3% in January with gains 13,000 less than the 143,000 jobs added a year ago, report showsThe US jobs market added 130,000 jobs in January, according to a highly anticipated labor market report released on Wednesday, a surge of job growth after months of fatigue in the labor market.The unemployment rate was 4.3% in January, a slight cooling since the fall. Economists predicted 70,000 in job gains and an unchanged unemployment rate for January. Continue reading...

items.title: U.S. unexpectedly adds 130,000 jobs in January after a weak 2025
items.standfirst: U.S. employers added 130,000 jobs in January as the unemployment rate dipped to 4.3% from 4.4% in December. Annual revisions show that job growth last year was far weaker than initially reported.
items.content: U.S. employers added 130,000 jobs in January as the unemployment rate dipped to 4.3% from 4.4% in December. Annual revisions show that job growth last year was far weaker than initially reported. (Image credit: Spencer Platt)

ai_summary: The US added 130000 jobs in January, surpassing expectations

items.standfirst: Marc Benioff’s remarks criticized as employees were reportedly planning to urge him to cancel business with agencyMarc Benioff, the Salesforce CEO and co-founder, is facing growing criticism over a joke he made about US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) monitoring international employees during an event for the company.Employees publicly expressed outrage about Benioff’s comments in his keynote address at an internal conference in Las Vegas on Tuesday, and leaders at Slack, which Salesforce owns, have said he should apologize. items.standfirst: The Dawson’s Creek star, who died on Tuesday aged 48, had been open about struggling to meet the high expenses of his cancer treatmentA GoFundMe set up to support the widow and children of actor James Van Der Beek has passed its initial goal of $500,000 within hours of being created – and has now been updated to a goal of $1m.Van Der Beek, best known for his role as sensitive teen Dawson Leery on the TV series Dawson’s Creek, died on Tuesday aged 48 after a battle with bowel cancer. Continue reading...

items.title: ‘Dawson’s Creek’ actor James Van Der Beek dies at 48
items.standfirst: US actor James Van Der Beek, best known for his role in the television series “Dawson’s Creek,” died on Wednesday at age 48 following a battle with colorectal cancer, according to a statement posted on his Instagram page. The married father of six revealed his diagnosis in 2024.
items.content: US actor James Van Der Beek, best known for his role in the television series “Dawson’s Creek,” died on Wednesday at age 48 following a battle with colorectal cancer, according to a statement posted on his Instagram page. The married father of six revealed his diagnosis in 2024.

items.title: EU leaders to clash over ‘Buy European’ push at Belgium summit
items.standfirst: Leaders to discuss once-taboo policy of favouring European companies, in attempt to regain economic competitivenessEU leaders are expected to diverge on whether “Buy European” is an answer to Europe’s waning economic fortunes, at a summit on how to secure the continent’s future in a more volatile global economy.At a moated castle in the east Belgian countryside, the EU’s 27 leaders will gather on Thursday for a brainstorming session on how Europe can regain its economic competitiveness vis-a-vis the US and China, at a time of economic threats and political turbulence. Continue reading...
items.content: Leaders to discuss once-taboo policy of favouring European companies, in attempt to regain economic competitivenessEU leaders are expected to diverge on whether “Buy European” is an answer to Europe’s waning economic fortunes, at a summit on how to secure the continent’s future in a more volatile global economy.At a moated castle in the east Belgian countryside, the EU’s 27 leaders will gather on Thursday for a brainstorming session on how Europe can regain its economic competitiveness vis-a-vis the US and China, at a time of economic threats and political turbulence. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Switzerland to vote on far-right proposal to cap population at 10 million
clusters.neutral_headline: Switzerland To Vote On Population Cap

items.title: Switzerland to vote on far-right proposal to cap population at 10 million
items.standfirst: Referendum on immigration limit could threaten EU agreements and cripple economy, say Swiss businesses Switzerland will vote this summer on a proposal from the far-right Swiss People’s party (SVP) to limit the country’s population to 10 million, a move that would threaten key agreements with the EU and, opponents say, cripple its economy.The government said on Wednesday the referendum on the SVP’s “No to a 10 million Switzerland” initiative, which is strongly opposed by both chambers of parliament and the business and financial services community, would be held on 10 June. Continue reading...
items.content: Referendum on immigration limit could threaten EU agreements and cripple economy, say Swiss businesses Switzerland will vote this summer on a proposal from the far-right Swiss People’s party (SVP) to limit the country’s population to 10 million, a move that would threaten key agreements with the EU and, opponents say, cripple its economy.The government said on Wednesday the referendum on the SVP’s “No to a 10 million Switzerland” initiative, which is strongly opposed by both chambers of parliament and the business and financial services community, would be held on 10 June. Continue reading...

items.title: Switzerland will vote on a population cap
items.standfirst: Unlike your college apartment, Switzerland might limit the number of people allowed to live there. Yesterday, the Swiss government scheduled a June referendum on whether the home of Toblerone should cap its population at 10 million. Promoted by a popular right-wing party, the ballot measure—which…
items.content: Unlike your college apartment, Switzerland might limit the number of people allowed to live there. Yesterday, the Swiss government scheduled a June referendum on whether the home of Toblerone should cap its population at 10 million. Promoted by a popular right-wing party, the ballot measure—which…

ai_summary: Switzerland will vote on a proposal to cap the population at 10 million
The referendum is scheduled for June 10
The proposal is promoted by the far-right Swiss People's party
The move could threaten EU agreements and cripple the economy
The government and businesses oppose the initiative
